newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria to cut Biochim bank capital gap $15 mln.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria to cut Biochim bank capital gap $15 mln.

text.p: Bulgaria will reduce a $15-million capital gap in the state Biochim Bank next week as part of attempts to find a new foreign partner to manage or take a stake in the bank, Finance Minister Muravei Radev said on Friday.
"On Monday, the government will complete the operation aimed at boosting the Biochim Bank negative capital to risk assets ratio to zero," Muravei Radev told Reuters.
Talks on a management contract with ABN AMRO NV, which had a "twinning" relationship with Biochim Bank failed earlier this week.

The Bank Consolidation Company, which manages state equity in commercial banks and holds some 98 percent in Biochim Bank, has sent letters to 25 potential strategic investors offering negotiations on a management contract or privatisation deal for the bank, said Radev.
The $15 million is now available from a $50-million stabilisation package aimed at boosting Biochim's capital to risk assets ratio and liquidity, which was launched in April.
Part of the scheme involved a finance ministry purchase of long-term bad loan bonds from Biochim at par value of $100. Some $20 million of bonds were bought so far.
Under banking standards, prescribed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), Bulgarian commercial banks are to have six percent capital to risk assets ratio by end-1997.
Under pledges to the IMF, Bulgaria should seal privatisation deals or management contracts for two of its operating state-owned banks by end-September.
The United Bulgarian Bank privatisation is awaiting a final approval by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) board on Tuesday, said Radev.
The EBRD will take 35 percent, Bulgaria's Bulbank will take 35 percent and the U.S. Oppenheimer & Co will take the remaining 30 percent.
